qas.question: What was 16 2/3 rpm speed used for?
Who developed the 33 1/3 rpm speed record?
What record format was created for use in Chrysler automobiles?
Why did Chrysler discontinue use of the Hifi 16 2/3 rpm record?
To the end of which era could you find 16 rpm setting on record players?

context: Some recordings, such as books for the blind, were pressed at 16 2⁄3 rpm. Prestige Records released jazz records in this format in the late 1950s; for example, two of their Miles Davis albums were paired together in this format. <a1_0>Peter Goldmark<a1_0/>, the man who developed the 33 1⁄3 rpm record, developed the <a2_0>Highway Hi-Fi 16 2⁄3 rpm record<a2_0/> to be played in Chrysler automobiles, but <a3_0>poor performance<a3_0/> of the system and weak implementation by Chrysler and Columbia led to the demise of the 16 2⁄3 rpm records. Subsequently, the 16 2⁄3 rpm speed was used for <a0_0>narrated publications<a0_0/> for the blind and visually impaired, and were never widely commercially available, although it was common to see new turntable models with a 16 rpm speed setting produced as late as the <a4_0>1970s<a4_0/>.
